Award.AwardTitle: Real algebraic and combinatorial structures in matrix spaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to apply mathematical tools to study objects from optimization, engineering, and statistics. The research involved will lead to a better understanding of the underlying mathematics and further the development and analysis of algorithms. Development of such theory benefits both the mathematical and broader scientific communities and strengthens the connections between them. Another important part of this project involves mentoring undergraduate and graduate students. Participation in this project will expose students to a wide range of fields in mathematics, impress upon them the importance of interdisciplinary research, and train them in the theory and computational skills needed to carry it out.

The broad goals of the proposed research are to develop computational techniques in real algebraic geometry and combinatorics in order to study objects arising in optimization and other applications. Real algebraic geometry is the study of solutions to polynomial equations and inequalities, which can describe a vast array of systems from engineering and science. Tropical geometry is a powerful tool for extracting discrete data from real algebraic sets as well as for constructing examples of real algebraic sets with desired properties. The proposed research applies these powerful mathematical tools to problems in linear algebra and convex optimization. Stable polynomials, determinants, and linear spaces of matrices are fundamental objects in these fields. A better understanding of their underlying geometry would advance these fields and the connections between them.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The PI and her graduate students submitted 11 articles to peer-reviewed journals or conference proceedings, 7 of which are already published. Four additional manuscripts were started during the tenure of this award are still in preparation. Two of the PI's graduate students also completed dissertations during this time.

This research has centered mainly on polynomials and solutions to polynomials equations with special structure over the real numbers.  For example, determinantal representations of hyperbolic polynomials are a central theme in the PI's research.  Part of the research for this award has been to construct determinantal representations for polynomials appearing in univariate moment problems as well as the study of numerical ranges of matrices.  This includes the dissertation work of one of the PI's graduate students. The PI also helped develop the theory of varieties of higher codimension with this real-rootedness property and analyze their combinatorial structure.

Another major component of the PI's research during the tenure of this award has been the development of the theory of completely log-concave polynomials and their applications in matroid theory and related Markov chains. Together with coauthors Anari, Liu, and Oveis Gharan, the PI used this theory to solve two 20+ year-old conjectures on matroids; one on the number of possible independent sets and the other on the expansion of its basis-exchange graph. These results are important in theoretical computer science because they enable fast sampling and approximate counting of a wide array of combinatorial structures.

The research from this award also includes other projects broadly involving applied algebraic geometry.  One is a paper coauthored by the PI's graduate student on maximum likelihood estimation in non-parametric statistics.  Another is a joint project with a different Ph.D. student on the differential signature of algebraic curves. This project has applications for image processing and computer vision and served as the basis for a dissertation of one of the PI's graduate students.


Broader Impacts

Mentoring. Over the tenure of this award, the PI has advised four Ph.D. students.  Two graduated in 2019 and the others are expected to graduate in 2021 and 2022, respectively. In addition to RA support and their travel to conferences, this award enabled three of them to attend the ICERM program on Nonlinear Algebra in the fall of 2018, which was an invaluable opportunity for them to broaden their mathematical horizons and make contacts with faculty and graduate students at other institutions.  The PI also advised a postdoc for one year and and mentored one year-long undergraduate research project.

Dissemination and Organization. Over the course of this award, the PI has disseminated her research by giving 42 research talks in seminars, conferences or workshops and 10 expository talks.  The PI co-organized 2 mini-symposia, 4 week-long workshops, one "Connections for Women" workshop at MSRI, and one semester long program at ICERM.  The PI also organized two local semester-long research working groups, one at NCSU and one at the Simons Institute for the Theory of Computing, at which she was a visitor. The PI also co-organized a weekly seminar at NCSU for mathematically inclined undergraduates.

Course development. In the spring of 2017, the PI ran an independent reading course with four graduate students on algorithms in invariant theory. In the spring of 2019, the PI developed a special topics graduate class on real algebraic geometry and convex optimization.  

Service to professional journals. During the tenure of this award, the PI was an associate editor for the American Mathematical Monthly and served as a referee for 27 journal articles.
